ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR: VIE 30286 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund)  
 
 
TO THE 
 
 
SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF VIET NAM 
 
 
FOR PREPARING THE 
 
 
CENTRAL REGION SMALL AND MEDIUM TOWNS  
 
 
DEVELOPMENT PROJECT 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 2004

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 31 October 2004) 
 
Currency Unit  –  dong (VND) 
VND1.00  –  $0.0000635243 
$1.00  –  VND15,742.00 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DPC  –  district people’s committee 
  MOC  –  Ministry of Construction 
  PPC  –  provincial people’s committee 
  PWC  –  provincial water supply company 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  WSS  –  water supply and sanitation 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  Targeted intervention 
Sector  –  Water supply, sanitation, and waste management 
Subsector  –  Integrated 
Theme  –  Sustainable economic growth, environmental sustainability, 
inclusive social development 
Subtheme  –  Fostering (physical) infrastructure development, urban 
environment, human development 
 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government and its agencies ends on 31 December. 
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by a team consisting of J. Hakim (team leader), A. Jain, B. Nguyen, 
 
L. Nazarbekova, and N. Ikemoto.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Following a request from the Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam (the 
Government) for a technical assistance (TA) to prepare the Central Region Small and Medium 
Towns Development Project, an Asian Development Bank (ADB) fact-finding mission visited 
Viet Nam, on 18–28 October 2004.1 The mission consulted with representatives of the Ministry 
of Construction (MOC), the State Bank of Viet Nam, the Ministry of Planning and Investment, 
the  Ministry  of  Finance,  as  well  as  representatives  of  the  provincial  and  district  people’s 
committees (PPCs and DPCs) in Khanh Hoa, Ninh Thuan, and Phu Yen provinces, which are 
within  the  likely  project  area.  The  mission  also  met  with  representatives  of  the  Agence 
Française de Développement (AFD), which has expressed initial interest in cofinancing the 
Project. Based on these discussions and field visits to the three provinces, the mission reached 
an understanding with the Government on the objectives, scope, cost estimates, financing plan, 
and implementation arrangements of the project preparatory TA, and the terms of reference for 
the consultants.2 The preliminary project framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.   ISSUES 
 
2.  Since the late 1980s, Viet Nam’s economic growth has been impressive. Between 1992 
and 2002, the poverty level decreased from around 54% to 29%.3 The engines of growth have 
been the urban centers, as highlighted by the growth of the industry and services sectors, which 
posted respective rates of 9.4% and 6.5% for 2001, and 8.9% and 6.0% for 2002. This extended 
period of high growth in the urban centers, however, has not been matched by investments in 
infrastructure, particularly in the small and medium towns. Despite government support for 
urban  development,  prolonged  periods  of  fiscal  deficits  have  restricted  the  investments 
necessary to improve the quality of life for the urban population. 
 
3.  As Viet Nam’s Millennium Development Goals and Targets emphasize the importance of 
improving the quality of life and public health, and, at the same time, promoting sustainable 
economic growth, the Government has attributed a high priority to water supply and sanitation 
(WSS) and considers these as strategic urban investments. The Government’s development 
strategies  and  policies  for  urban  water  supply  are  reflected  in  the  Orientation  Plan  for 
Development of Water Supply to 2020, approved in March 1998. The geographic focus of the 
proposed project is the southern Central Region, one of the poorest regions in Viet Nam with 
poverty levels higher than the national average. The urban population in the region was about 
4.5 million in 2003 and is growing at an average annual rate of 4.7%.  
 
4.  The mission’s findings supported the Government’s position that inadequate WSS were 
the most pressing issues in the small and medium towns in the southern Central Region. 
Seasonal occurrences of flood and drought have plagued the region; the lack of investments 
and deteriorated conditions of urban WSS facilities have heightened environmental and health 
risks and have inhibited the social and economic development of the region’s small and medium 
towns. Most towns have either inadequate or no water supply system at all, with a maximum 
service coverage of 20%. A large proportion of the population uses water from contaminated or 
saline wells and surface sources. Many residents purchase water for drinking and cooking from 
vendors or from residents connected to public water supplies, at extremely high prices, often 5–
                                                 
1  The TA is included in the Viet Nam Country Strategy and Program Update, 2005–2006. 
2  The TA first appeared in  ADB Business Opportunities  (Internet edition) on 19 November 1998 under the title 
“Central Region Sustainable Urban Development.” The last updated version was made on 6 November 2004. 
3  Respective figures by the World Bank and Viet Nam’s General Statistics Office.

2  
20 times existing tariffs for public water supply. On the supply side, problems of inadequate 
management and lack of technical capacity have resulted in poor maintenance of the existing 
systems, to the extent that most of them require replacement. 
 
5.  A severe lack of drainage was evident in all towns visited by the mission, which is clearly 
leading to problems of flooding and difficulties in accessibility. Surface drainage systems were 
either nonexistent or in serious need of repair, and environmental pollution resulting from waste 
discharges  lead  to  serious  health  risks.  Solid  waste  collection  was  lacking  and  leads  to 
unsanitary  disposal,  indiscriminate  dumping,  and  contamination  of  the  general  urban 
environment.  Latrine  systems  (identified  as  septic  tanks)  have  open  bottom  pits,  which 
discharge  wastewater  into  the  soil,  causing  serious  health  hazards  associated  with 
contamination. Aside from the absence of sanitation facilities,  there is also a lack of health 
awareness and education among the urban poor.  
 
6.  As most provinces and districts in the southern Central Region are net recipients of the 
national government budget, they have limited financial resources for capital investments and 
operation and maintenance support. This has not only impeded development, but has also 
restricted the ability of local authorities to build any degree of capacity in urban services 
management. There is a need to provide a structured capacity-building program, support for the 
sustainability  of  improved  urban  services,  and  an  enhanced  sense  of  local  ownership  of 
investments.  
 
7.  ADB  has  actively  assisted  Viet  Nam’s  urban  and  WSS  sectors  since  1993,  with 
emphasis on new water supply systems, rehabilitation and extension of existing systems, 
environmental  and  infrastructure  improvements,  capacity  building,  and  institutional  reform. 
Since 1993, ADB has approved five loans totaling $304 million equivalent4 and provided several 
advisory  TA  grants.  The  recommendations  resulting  from  these  interventions  have  been 
accepted by the Government and have helped develop the national water supply tariff policy, 
strengthen water supply companies, and facilitate urban environmental improvements. Further 
efforts to improve WSS conditions will reduce poverty through improved health conditions, 
increased time and cost savings for women who conveniently collect safe water for daily 
consumption, and improved community and family hygiene. 
 
8.  Several lessons learned could be extracted from previous implementation experience. 
First is that, given the geographic length of the country—1,500 kilometers north to south—the 
towns to be supported by the Project should be clustered to facilitate effective administration 
and coordination during implementation. The TA will therefore cover towns in five contiguous 
provinces of the southern Central Region, with poverty levels above the national average. 
Second, there is a need to carefully prioritize investments. The TA will either refer to an existing 
investment plan or design one that will provide a framework for future development. The third 
lesson is that broad-based participation is essential to the success of any project. Participation 
                                                 
4  ADB. 1993. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the 
Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Ho Chi Minh Water Supply and Sanitation Project. Manila; ADB. 1995. Report 
and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the Socialist Republic of 
Viet Nam for  the Provincial Towns Water Supply and Sanitation Project. Manila; ADB. 1997. Report and 
Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the Socialist Republic of Viet 
Nam for the Second Provincial Towns Water Supply and Sanitation Project. Manila; ADB. 2001.  Report and 
Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the Socialist Republic of Viet 
Nam for the Third Provincial Towns Water Supply and Sanitation Project. Manila; and ADB. 2003. Report and 
Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the Socialist Republic of Viet 
Nam for the Central Region Urban Environmental Improvements Project. Manila.

3
can only be instilled by a sense of ownership, and for that purpose, consultation with key 
stakeholders is imperative. Fourth, is that the effectiveness of PPCs, provincial water supply 
companies (PWCs), DPCs, urban environmental companies, and other stakeholders has been 
constrained by the policy environment and limited capacity to provide adequate and sustainable 
WSS services in southern Central Region towns. A firm commitment from government at all 
levels is needed to support reform efforts. Last is the importance of establishing a management 
framework that will systematically evaluate and monitor environmental, involuntary resettlement, 
and other social impacts to fully comply with safeguard policies and ensure sustainable WSS 
development.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
9.  The development goal of the Project under preparation is to reduce poverty and improve 
the quality of life of the urban population in the target areas through sustainable improvements 
in WSS. The purpose of the TA is to prepare a pre-investment study and project design for 
small and medium towns in Viet Nam’s southern Central Region. The objectives of the TA are to 
(i) identify socioeconomic, WSS, and water resource conditions and needs in the candidate 
project towns; (ii) assess managerial, technical, and financial capacity of WSS providers as well 
as potential for broad-based participation; (iii) ensure that social and environmental safeguards 
are met; and (iv) prepare a project design suitable for sustainable WSS improvements of 10–20 
small and medium town environments in five contiguous provinces in the southern Central 
Region.5 TA outputs are: (i) a study for WSS development for southern central region small and 
medium towns to include an inception, interim, draft final, and final report; (ii) social and 
environmental safeguard documents, (iii) a pre-investment study and design of WSS and WSS-
related  components,  broad-based  participatory  activities,  and  capacity  building  of  WSS 
providers and regulators, and (iv) downstream commitments to fund future implementation of 
the  project.  The  design  will  include  physical  investments;  project  costs  and  financing 
mechanisms; operation and maintenance procedures; recommended policy, institutional, and 
regulatory reform; and managerial, technical, and financial capacity building. The TA will also 
develop WSS investment plans for the towns where no such plan exists.  
 
10.  The mission discussed with MOC several components to be considered for project 
preparation. These include water supply development, sanitation infrastructure improvements, 
public awareness and health education programs, and implementation assistance and capacity 
building. The water supply development component will propose new water supply systems, 
rehabilitation and further extensions of existing systems, and community-based water supply 
systems where appropriate. Sanitation improvements will comprise drainage, sewage disposal, 
and solid waste management. Public awareness programs will engage mass organizations such 
as women’s and youth unions to educate the public regarding good health practices, conduct 
cleanliness campaigns, and engage communities in collective activities that encourage broad-
based participation for the operation and maintenance of investments. A strong emphasis will be 
placed on strengthening the managerial, technical, and financial capacities of PWCs, urban 
environmental corporations, PPCs, and DPCs to ensure sustainability of WSS facilities after 
project completion, and strengthening the Viet Nam Water Supply and Sewerage Association to 
                                                 
5  The number of towns could be expanded to up to 20, depending on the cost of subproject components and on the 
availability of cofinancing. Final selection will be based on predetermined criteria to include (i) poverty level, 
(ii) need  for  assistance,  (iii) commitment  and  capacity  of  the  PPC/DPC,  (iv) compatibility  with  the  agreed 
geographic focus, (v) existence of a master plan, and (vi) no previous ADB assistance in the sector.

4  
enable it to perform its function as a regulatory body. In addition, policy, institutional, and 
regulatory  amendments  to  the  existing  frameworks  will  be  undertaken  for  further  sector 
development. An analysis of cost recovery through improved tariffs, as well as the potential for 
private sector participation, will also be explored.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will conduct a review of the WSS sector, including lessons learned from previous 
projects assisted by ADB, the Government, and development partners. An assessment of the 
current level of WSS services and water resources, as well as institutional, policy, and human 
resource conditions will be made to identify opportunities and constraints facing WSS sector 
development in the project towns. Data will be collected through surveys, interviews, focus 
group  discussions,  and  secondary  data  sources  to  assess  WSS  needs  and  potential  for 
community  participation  and  private  sector  involvement.  Surveys  will  be  targeted  at  the 
household level, while interviews and focus group discussions will target specific groups such 
as females, the youth, community leaders, and government authorities. Opinions from various 
groups will provide the necessary inputs to design project parameters and to ensure broad-
based participation and support for the project. Workshops and consultative meetings will be 
held to sensitize communities and local government officials on project objectives, obtain their 
support, and disseminate the findings of the project preparatory TA. 
 
12.  A  participatory  approach  will  be  undertaken  to  ensure  that  the  WSS  facilities  and 
capacity-building programs for each project town will be demand-driven. The TA will undertake 
the following activities: (i) review information and evaluate previous WSS projects by ADB, 
Government, and development partners; (ii) prepare and implement field surveys to assess the 
socio-economic status of urban residents and the situation regarding WSS services; (iii) prepare 
gender, social and cultural assessment, and necessary action plans, along with measures to 
mitigate  adverse  impacts  on  minority  communities;  (iv)  assess  resettlement  impacts  and 
requirements  and  prepare  resettlement  framework  and  plans;  (v)  prepare  environmental 
examinations and plan containing necessary mitigation measures; (vi) prepare a financial and 
economic  analysis;  (vii)  prepare  institutional  assessment  and  institutional  development 
programs; (viii) conduct workshops to obtain critical inputs from stakeholders; (ix) identify and 
delineate project components and subprojects; and (x) implement overall project management 
and progress reporting.  
 
13.  An initial poverty and social assessment, which examines preliminary poverty conditions, 
minority issues, resettlement effects, gender issues, and vulnerable groups is in Appendix 2. All 
resettlement, environmental, and social assessments will be carried out according to ADB 
safeguard procedures as indicated in the consultants’ terms of reference in Appendix 3. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.2 million equivalent, comprising $694,000 in 
foreign  exchange  cost  and  $506,000  equivalent  in  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will  provide 
$950,000 equivalent to cover the entire foreign exchange cost and $256,000 equivalent of the 
local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded 
by the Government of Japan. The Government contribution of $250,000 equivalent will cover 
the provision of office accommodation and facilities, remuneration of counterpart staff, provision 
of workshop facilities, and domestic travel costs and per diem. Cost estimates and financing 
arrangements are in Appendix 4. The Government has been advised that approval of the TA 
does not commit ADB to finance the ensuing project.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  MOC will be the Executing Agency for the TA. A project coordination unit, attached to 
the Management Board for Urban Technical Infrastructure Development Projects will implement 
the TA on behalf of MOC, as the coordinating agency at the central level. The PPC or DPC of 
the  selected  project  area  will  be  the  implementing  agency,  which  will  set  up  a  project 
preparation unit comprising technical staff from relevant departments. The PWC will be the 
counterpart for preparing  the  design  of  the  water  supply  component.  A project steering 
committee, to be chaired by a senior official of MOC, with members from the senior staff of the 
Ministry of Planning and Investment, Ministry of Finance, State Bank of Viet Nam, participating 
PPCs/DPCs,  and  the  Management  Board  for  Urban  Technical  Infrastructure  Development 
Projects will be established prior to fielding the consultants. It will be convened to review and 
endorse the consultants’ reports at each stage of the study, and/or at the request of any 
member to discuss major policy and implementation issues.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 8 months from 15 February 2005 to 15 October 2005. 
An international consulting firm will be selected using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method in association with local consulting firms or individual domestic consultants. It will 
require  approximately  83  person-months  of  consulting  services  (23  person-months  of 
international and 60 person-months of domestic consultant input) with expertise in water supply 
and sanitation engineering, institutional development, environmental assessment, economic and 
financial  analysis,  social  development,  gender,  and  resettlement.  The consultants will be 
recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of domestic consultants. Outline terms of 
reference on the consulting services are given in Appendix 3. Equipment to be provided under 
the TA will be purchased in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. All bidders, 
suppliers, contractors, and consultants shall be required to observe the highest standards of 
ethics in procuring and executing ADB-financed contracts and shall be subject to sanctions if 
fraud and corruption are discovered. 
 
17.  The consultants will submit to ADB the following reports: (i) an inception report within 3 
weeks of mobilization, which contains a summary of the assignment and TA background, 
methodology/approach, staffing and personnel, scheduling of activities, and project design 
parameters; (ii) an interim report within 4 months of mobilization, which includes survey and 
workshop findings and a preliminary project design for all project towns; (iii) a draft final report 
containing a refinement of the  interim report, to be submitted within 6 months of consultant 
mobilization; (iv) a prefeasibility report, to be submitted to the Government of Viet Nam; (v) a 
draft final report/feasibility study; and (vi) final report at the end of the TA. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
  
18.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for preparing the Central Region Small 
and Medium Towns Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 2  9 
INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
Is the sector identified as a national 
Is  the  sector  identified  as  a  national    Yes   Yes 
priority in country poverty partnership 
priority in country poverty analysis?       No    No 
agreement?   
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
Viet Nam has experienced rapid economic growth and urbanization over the past decade. Gross domestic product 
(GDP) maintained an average annual growth of about 7% and the urban population ratio has increased from 20% in 
1990 to about 25% in 2003. The urban population in the Central Region totaled close to 4.5 million in 2003 and is 
growing at 4.7% per annum. Over the last decade, the urban infrastructure has been unable to meet the increasing 
demands of the growing urban population due to insufficient funds and limited institutional capacity. This imbalance 
heightens environmental and health risks, and inhibits social and economic development of urban people in the 
Central Region. 
 
The proposed technical assistance (TA) will be used to prepare a water supply and sanitation project for Viet Nam’s 
small and medium towns in the southern Central Region. The Project will contribute toward the achievement of the 
Millennium Development Goals and Targets. Improved water supply and sanitation has the potential of (i) increasing 
time and cost-savings for women who collect, treat, and store water for daily consumption; (ii) improving community 
and family hygiene and health practices; (iii) reducing health care expenditures for households, especially for the poor 
and vulnerable; and (iv) improving individual well-being, which implies better health, increased productive days, and 
higher school attendance. The proposed Project will cover services in 10–20 towns, including 10 towns in the five 
provinces of Phu Yen, Khanh Hoa, Ninh Thuan, Binh Thuan, and Dak Nong. With the exception of Dak Nong, eight 
towns are accessible by National Road 1A and by a parallel rail line. A community health and hygiene program will 
help expand services to the poor and low-income areas. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                         Proposed Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
The southern Central Region is one of the poorest in Viet Nam. The living standards are often lower with poverty 
levels higher than the national average. Poor and near-poor households are the most vulnerable to inadequate urban 
infrastructure and unsanitary conditions. The urban poor in the candidate project towns live in underserved areas with 
either inadequate water supply or nonexistent sanitation facilities, or both. For instance, the poor and low-income 
households are fishing households that reside along the coastal areas in Phu Yen, Khanh Hoa, and Ninh Thuan. Poor 
toilet and septic tank facilities add to unsanitary conditions and environmental pollution. The poor also suffer from 
dysfunctional or nonexistent drainage, frequent flooding, and limited access to solid waste collection. Improving water 
supply and sanitation will reduce vulnerability associated with high health care expenditures due to environmental 
sickness.  
 
A poverty analysis will be carried out to summarize the causes of poverty in the project towns, identify areas of high 
poverty incidence, prepare a complementary community-based water supply and sanitation program, assist in 
quantifying the benefits of the proposed Project in reducing poverty, and incorporate other social measures within the 
scope of project implementation. The poverty analysis will focus the poverty impact of the proposed interventions on 
the poor and disadvantaged, including the contribution of the Project to reducing access barriers to water supply and 
sanitation services for the poor and the near-poor. Participatory methods will help address the needs of the poor, and 
strengthen the pro-poor focus of the Project. The analysis will also include opportunities for generating new 
employment and of enhancing community ownership and self-reliance. The analysis will be part of an overall poverty 
and social strategy for the Project. In the case of possibilities for employment, reference will be made for compliance 
to internationally recognized core labor standards as well as the country’s labor legislation. 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
A stakeholder analysis will be required to identify key project stakeholders, their project-related interests, and the ways 
in which they affect project feasibility and success. Primary stakeholders include town residents, people and 
institutions affected by land acquisition and resettlement, ethnic minority people, vulnerable groups, rural populations 
around the town areas, and tourism and natural resource developers (e.g., salt and glass manufacturers). Secondary 
stakeholders include the Ministry of Construction, provincial and local people’s committees, and relevant government 
agencies. The role of stakeholders will be disaggregated by age, gender, and ethnicity where possible. The role of 
mass organizations (e.g., women’s union, youth union) and nongovernment organizations will also be considered. 
 
Participation and consultation will be carried out with the above stakeholders during project preparation. Participatory 
rural appraisal techniques will be used in designing project components, implementation, operation and maintenance, 
and  monitoring  and  evaluation  arrangements.  The  process  will  involve  information  sharing,  consultations, 
socioeconomic surveys, interviews, focus group meetings, workshops, participatory rural appraisal, and collaborative 
decision making. Records of consultations will be noted and included in the poverty and social assessment and

1100  Appendix 2 
decision making. Records of consultations will be noted and included in the poverty and social assessment and 
strategy. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
Based on stakeholder consultations, a participation strategy will be development. The strategy will delineate ways in 
which to enhance key stakeholders and beneficiaries participation, and will be key to the community-based health and 
hygiene  component,  poverty  and  social  strategy,  resettlement  plans,  and  initial  environmental  examinations. 
Participation will also involve affected persons in developing resettlement plans. 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
In Viet Nam, females make up about 50% of the total population, and are generally responsible for a conducting a 
variety of tasks related to water and sanitation. During project preparation, a detailed gender analysis will be 
conducted to determine how to better maximize project benefits for women. The purpose will be to address the needs 
and interests of women, especially female-headed households, and suggest measures on ways of maximizing their 
benefits from the proposed Project. Particular attention will be given on ways to increase women’s representation and 
enhance  their  decision-making  capabilities  through  awareness,  capacity  building,  and  employment.  Women’s 
participation in mass organizations and provincial and district/town peoples committees will also be considered.   
 
Has an output been prepared?      Yes     No 
A gender strategy will be developed during project preparation and integrated into an overall poverty and social 
strategy.  Specific  gender  concerns  for  women  facing  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  will  be  addressed  in 
resettlement plans. 
E.  Social Safeguards and Other Social Risks 
Significant/ 
Plan 
 Item  Not Significant/  Strategy to Address Issues  Required 
None 
Land  acquisition  and  resettlement  is  not  expected  to  be 
significant, as it will be avoided or minimized whenever possible. 
A  resettlement  plan  for  each  province  will  be  prepared  in 
accordance with government regulations and ADB’s  policy on 
 Significant   Full 
involuntary resettlement. Each resettlement plan will contain land 
Resettlement   Not significant  Short 
acquisition  and  resettlement  planning  for  each  town  project 
 None   None  
within that province. The purpose of the resettlement plan is to 
ensure that affected people are compensated at replacement 
costs, and are able to regain, if not improve their pre-project 
living standards.  
When setting the levels of service charges, ability to pay of the

household, particularly the poor and low-income households, will   Yes

affected people will be given opportunities for project-related

country’s labor legislation, as well as the Core Labor Standard.

Appendix 3  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consulting firm will have broad experience in all aspects of water supply and 
sanitation  development,  community  participation,  and  capacity  building  as  well  as  needed 
expertise in economic, financial, and social analyses. The international gender specialist will be 
recruited separately but will work under the supervision of the Team Leader. Consultants will 
provide the following reports: (i) an inception report within 3 weeks of mobilization; (ii) an interim 
report within 4 months of mobilization; (iii) a draft final report within 6 months of consultant 
mobilization; (iv) a prefeasibility report, to be submitted to the Government of Viet Nam; and 
(v) a final report/feasibility study. The terms of reference for the consulting team will be as 
follows: 
 
A.  Institutional Development Specialist/Team Leader (international, 7 person-months). 
The consultant will carry out the following tasks:  
 
(i)   coordinate the work of all international and domestic consultants in conducting 
assessments,  surveys,  workshops,  design  development,  report  writing,  and 
overall management of the consultant team; and ni corporate lessons learned 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) as well as other development partners 
in the water supply and sanitation (WSS) sector;  
 
(ii)   identify key stakeholders and relationships among key WSS sector institutions 
and their regulatory functions at the central, provincial, and local government 
levels. Analyze local administration structures, personnel management, budget, 
standard and productivity norms, decision-making processes, and relations with 
the public pertaining to the provision and delivery of WSS services. Analyze WSS 
policies, regulations, strategies, and programs; 
 
(iii)  identify policy, institutional, and human resource constraints facing water supply 
and  drainage  companies,  and  public  works  companies  under  the  various 
provincial  people’s  committee  (PPC)  and  district  people’s  committee  (DPC) 
authorities in providing efficient and responsive WSS services at the local level. 
Review current legislation, regulations, and decrees pertaining to the provision of 
WSS services and recommend the necessary policy and institutional reforms 
needed to develop the WSS sector; 
 
(iv)  review existing training programs provided the Viet Nam Water Supply and 
Sewerage Association, PPCs, provincial water supply companies (PWCs) and 
DPCs, and identify gaps and needs for managerial, technical, and administrative 
training.  Identify  appropriate  participants  for  training  sessions  for  potential 
trainers and prepare a training program in the project towns for key staff in 
charge of WSS services; 
 
(v)  assess the constraints to civic and private sector participation in WSS sector 
development  and  the  current  and  potential  modalities  for  their  involvement; 
Identify the areas for improving the regulatory and institutional environment; 
 
(vi)  prepare  an  institutional  analysis,  which  includes  an  overview  of  the  current 
institutional framework for WSS, identification of key stakeholders, constraints to 
effective and affordable WSS provision and delivery, and recommendations for 
necessary  policy,  legal,  administrative,  and  organizational  reforms  and 
improvements in consultation with relevant agencies and ADB. Suggest areas for

1122  Appendix 3 
intervention to improve governance and management, and build capacity  with 
respect to WSS service provision and effective sector regulation.  
 
B.    Economic and Financial Analyst  (international, 2.5 person-months). The consultant 
will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  review ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects, Handbook for the 
Economic Analysis of Water Supply Projects, Framework for the Economic and 
Financial Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects, Economic Analysis in 
2002:  A  Retrospective,  Economic  Analysis  Retrospective,  2003  Update, 
Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis 
of Projects, and Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in the Economic Analysis 
of Projects; 
 
(ii)  review  the  socioeconomic  development  plans  of  participating  provinces  and 
towns, describe the macroeconomic and sectoral context within which the Project 
will  be  implemented,  and  establish  the  rationale  for  public  sector  and  ADB 
involvement. Provide inputs for design of the socioeconomic survey and collect 
the necessary data required for economic analysis; 
 
(iii)  prepare, for each project town, an economic analysis covering,  among other 
things,  demand  analysis,  least  economic  cost  analysis,  economic  cost  and 
benefit analysis, economic internal rates of return, average incremental economic 
costs, sensitivity analysis, risk analysis, benefit distributional analysis, poverty 
impact ratios, and assessment of subsidies. If subsidies are needed, provide 
their rationale and justification, in line with ADB’s Criteria for Subsidies.  
 
(iv)  review  the  tariff  policies,  current  tariff  levels  and  structures,  and  collection 
mechanisms for various urban services and recommend user charges for public 
services documented in Economics and Research Department [ERD] Technical 
Note Series, No. 9. Assess the pricing of services for the poor, willingness to pay, 
ability to pay of different user groups, cost-sharing mechanisms, and funds-flow 
arrangements;  
 
(v)  review  the  fiscal  linkages  between  the  central,  provincial,  and  district/town 
governments. Examine the existing financial positions of the provincial and local 
governments  that  will  lend/relend  funds  or  provide  counterpart  funds  to  the 
Project. Prepare 5-year financial projections and assess the affordability of the 
proposed subprojects; 
 
(vi)  prepare, for each project town, a financial analysis, covering, among other things, 
financial cost and benefits analysis, calculation of average incremental financial 
cost, financial internal rates of return, and sensitivity analysis with respect to 
project design and implementation risks; 
 
(vii)  review  related  accounting  standards  and  policies  and  financial  management 
institutional  arrangements,  assess  the  financial  management  capacities  of 
related  provincial,  local  governments  and  urban  project  companies/units, 
recommend measures to strengthen their financial management capacities, and 
prepare the terms of reference for consulting services.

Appendix 3  1133 
(viii)  prepare an evaluation of the value-added provided by this technical assistance to 
Viet Nam’s development.  
 
C.  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  Engineer  (international,  7  person-months).  The 
consultant will carry out the following tasks: 
   
(i)  collect and analyze WSS and related information, including topography, soil, 
water resources, land use, major industries, existing WSS coverage, willingness 
to pay; main drainage patterns, storm water and wastewater flows, organic and 
other pollution loads, catchment areas, and drainage routes; and groundwater 
samples for testing and identify pollution levels and samples of receiving waters 
during the wet and dry seasons. Sink shallow boreholes as needed to determine 
water quality; 
 
(ii)  review existing policies, plans, reports, standards, and studies relating to the 
water resource and WSS infrastructure investments, physical planning, design 
and management. Recommend improvements to ensure good practices; 
 
(iii)  prepare and evaluate conceptual designs of alternative WSS systems to include 
management schemes, production and distribution, operation and maintenance, 
and financing mechanisms; 
 
(iv)  prepare detailed cost estimates for each subproject and provide summaries by 
project and component for land and resettlement, civil works, equipment and 
materials,  consulting  services,  project  management,  taxes  and  duties,  and 
interest and other charges during construction. In collaboration with the financial 
analyst,  prepare  a  WSS  investment  plan  and  operation  and  maintenance 
procedures for each project town; 
 
(v)  prepare  prefeasibility  and  feasibility  studies  and  preliminary  designs  for  all 
components  of  all  project  towns  in  accordance  with  ADB  and  Viet  Nam 
government regulations. Describe in detail the scope of each component, and 
recommend  the  packaging  of  contracts.  Prepare  a  benefit  monitoring  and 
evaluation plan in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on Benefit Monitoring and 
Evaluation. 
 
D.  Social Development Specialist  (international, 2 person-months). The consultant will 
carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  conduct  a  socioeconomic  survey  in  collaboration  with  other  specialists,  and 
prepare  socioeconomic  and  poverty  profiles  for  project  towns  to  include 
population, income, occupation, and education levels; and health conditions, to 
be disaggregated by income group, ethnic group, and gender, to serve as the 
baseline  for  poverty  and  social  monitoring.  Review  provincial  and  local 
government policies, strategies, and programs for poverty reduction and regional 
economic development as they pertain to the project towns; 
 
(ii)  prepare a poverty and social analysis, using participatory methods in accordance 
with  the  draft  ADB  Handbook  for  Poverty  and  Social  Analysis and ADB’s 
Guidelines for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Bank Operations to assess 
the type and significance of the project impacts on the poor, ethnic minorities,

1144  Appendix 3 
and other vulnerable groups. If necessary, prepare a separate ethnic minority 
development plan according to ADB’s policy on indigenous peoples (1998) and in 
close consultation with the ethnic minority groups and relevant agencies; 
 
(iii)  conduct a public perception survey to identify public problems, satisfaction with 
the level of urban services, development priorities, and perceptions toward local 
authority administration efficiency, quality of urban services, and willingness to 
pay for improved WSS services. Prepare a community health education and 
hygiene  awareness  program  with  a  special  focus  on  women  and  children. 
Explore  possibilities  for  establishing  a  grant  fund  for  the  improvement  and 
construction of WSS facilities with community participation; 
 
(iv)  prepare a poverty and social strategy, which includes both special enhancement 
and  necessary  mitigation  measures  with  target  beneficiary  groups, 
implementation  arrangements,  estimated  budget,  and  monitoring  indicators 
based on the poverty and social analyses and assessment of potential impacts 
on ethnic minorities. Provide a summary of consultations held with all stakeholders 
and develop social action plans for each candidate project town; and 
 
(v)  prepare a draft participation strategy for community-based WSS schemes as well 
as  activities  for  other  project  components,  which  outlines  stakeholders’ 
involvement at different stages of the project cycle for each project town. Assess 
the  capacity  of  the  implementing  agency  and  other  concerned  agencies  in 
effectively implementing suggested poverty, social, and resettlement measures. 
 
D.  Gender Specialist (international, 1.5 person-month). The consultant will carry out the 
following tasks: 
 
(i)  review provincial and local government policies, strategies, and programs for 
poverty reduction and regional economic development as they relate to gender. 
Provide inputs to the socioeconomic survey and provide the necessary data and 
information  on  gender  to  the  social  development  specialist  for  further 
incorporation in the social and poverty analysis; 
 
(ii)  in collaboration with the social development specialist, prepare a community 
health  education  and  hygiene  awareness  program  with  a  special  focus  on 
women and children; and 
 
(iii)  prepare a gender analysis in accordance with ADB’s  Policy on Gender and 
Development and using the Gender Checklist for Water Supply and Sanitation. 
Prepare a gender development strategy with specific actions to address the 
needs of women, enhance their roles, and maximize their benefits from the 
Project.  Indicate  targets,  implementing  agency,  estimated  budget,  proposed 
timing, and monitoring indicators for any actions. Use participatory methods to 
help assess the type and significance of the gender-specific impacts.  
 
F.  Resettlement Specialist  (international, 1.5 person-months). The consultant will carry 
out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  review government policies and strategies on resettlement and collaborate with 
other  specialists  to  ensure  resettlement  implementation  arrangements  are

Appendix 3  1155 
integrated into the overall project design and include any gender-specific impacts 
of land acquisition and resettlement; 
 
(ii)  assess the land acquisition and resettlement requirements of the Project in each 
project town, and options to avoid or minimize resettlement. Provide an inventory 
of loss, and a socioeconomic survey of the affected populations.  Document 
consultations with all stakeholders held during the preparation of resettlement 
documents for inclusion into the plan; 
 
(iii)  prepare one resettlement framework for the Project and one resettlement plan 
per  province  according  to  Government  regulations  and  ADB’s  policy  on 
involuntary resettlement (1995) and ADB’s Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide 
to Good Practice (1998) to include separate estimates for land acquisition and 
resettlement impacts for each town within that one province; and 
 
(iv)  prepare, for each project town, a resettlement plan to include an entitlement 
matrix, a detailed budget with unit costs estimates based on replacement costs 
for  lost  assets,  implementation  schedules,  management  arrangements,  and 
arrangements for internal and external monitoring and evaluation. Conduct a 
replacement cost survey to determine unit replacement costs of assets lost.  
 
G.  Environmental Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). The consultant will carry 
out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  assess the environmental impacts of the of the proposed Project to include, but 
not  be  limited  to,  water  supply,  sanitation,  drainage,  sewerage,  solid  waste 
disposal, and other necessary infrastructure works. Include direct and indirect 
impacts during construction and operation, and their cumulative impacts; 
 
(ii)  collect  data  on  environmental  conditions  of  the  candidate  project  towns,  to 
include an inventory of natural and man-made resources, and the links between 
them. Identify climatic, topographical, and ecological patterns that may affect or 
be affected by the proposed Project; 
 
(iii)  prepare an initial environmental examination (IEE) for the overall Project and for 
each subproject town, a summary initial environmental examination to cover the 
overall  Project  and  sample  subprojects,  and  where  necessary,  prepare  an 
environmental impact assessment in accordance with ADB's Environment Policy 
(2002)  and  ADB's  Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines  (2003),  and  in 
accordance with the Government's environmental assessment requirements and 
review procedures; 
 
(iv)  assist the Executing Agency In securing environmental clearance certificates for 
each  subproject  as  required  by  the  Government  and  prepare  necessary 
information to comply with ADB and government  guidelines; and 
 
(v)  recommend (i) measures to safeguard the environment before, during, and after 
implementation  of  the  Project;  (ii) mitigation  measures  and  the  monitoring 
program, including cost implications, and an institutional setup for undertaking 
the program; and (iii) the responsible agency for environmental monitoring during 
project implementation.
